I got this done, and it works! For some reason, Jenkins is unhappy, even though the code compiles and the test cases pass.

Yay, Jenkins passes! Had to clean up the formatting a little, as clang-format locally did not agree with Jenkins, and also the old Makefile path still has to be maintained, as Jenkins does "make check" which still uses the old Make way.

- Seems doesn't support for Static JSON file?

- More thinking about this feature, with the current EM settings seem to be the same?
Ex:
{
  ...
  "Type": "Pid",
  "Class": "margin",
  "Inputs": [
    "temp1",
    "temp2"
  ],
  "TempToMargin": {
    85,
    95
  },
  "SetPoint": 10.0,
  "Zones": [
    "Zone 0"
  ]
  ...
}

Same as,
{
  ...
  "Type": "Pid",
  "Class": "temp",
  "Inputs": [
    "temp1"
  ],
  "SetPoint": 75.0,
  "Zones": [
    "Zone 0"
  ]
  ...
},
{
  ...
  "Type": "Pid",
  "Class": "temp",
  "Inputs": [
    "temp2"
  ],
  "SetPoint": 85.0,
  "Zones": [
    "Zone 0"
  ]
  ...
}
Set as unresolved

It should support Static JSON. See the pid/buildjson.cpp file. As is convention with existing static JSON, parameter names are in lowerSnakeCase, so it's named "tempToMargin" there.

Splitting up the PID loops like that would be one option. However, it is often preferable to have multiple sensors in the same PID loop.
Oh, sorry for missing checking pid/buildjson.cpp.
Thanks for looking at this.
Any other concerns here?

Sorry for being late. It occurred to me, does "TempToMargin" need to add to EM's schemas?
https://github.com/openbmc/entity-manager/blob/master/schemas/pid.json
It might. It works just fine as-is, though.
I have a change ready for the entity-manager schema: https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/entity-manager/+/61118

If we design SensorInput as base class and have derived classes for each type of sensor? Will that reduce the complexity of dbus/dbusconfiguration.cpp::init(). 

For example today convertTempToMargin is applicable to only PidClass = Margin, but if we decide that we need to convertPowerToMargin, then this structure may become more complex.

But this will be larger change.

True, I thought about adding a multiplier/offset in there as well. That would be for a future feature. The advantage of the struct here is that I can add more to it as needed, and not have it just be a number.

I think adding base/derived classes for this would increase complexity, not reduce it.
missing splitName() here?

No, it is intentional here. I want to pass in the complete vector of SensorInput structures, since this is a thermal PID loop. The splitName() function is only to support fan and stepwise loops, in which TempToMargin is intentionally not supported.
Not all `std::cerr` are controlled by debugEnabled.

That is true. The program prints some output unconditionally. That's the way it's always been. To hide all output under debugEnabled would be the subject of another change, not related to this change.

So..."Inputs" and "TempToMargin" name and value have to one-by-one. User have to write temp sensors first and then margin sensors.

Is there any other method that lets the user hasn't this limitation?
For example, set "None" for margin sensors in "TempToMargin".

I actually tried that earlier. Unfortunately, it would require changes in entity-manager, which are beyond the scope of this feature. I tried to have the value be a JSON object in my first proposed syntax: https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-pid-control/issues/23

It didn't work, because entity-manager has strict limitations on the allowed types of a value. I had to make it a simple list of floating-point numbers instead. Yes, they match up 1:1 with sensors in "Inputs". If the user is mixing temperature sensors and margin sensors in the same PID loop, then margin sensors need to come at the end of the list.
This has been ready to go for a while. Any thoughts? Corresponding schema update is here: https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/entity-manager/+/61118
Thanks for review, will make the fixes.

Yay, the interface has been merged! https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/entity-manager/+/61118

We are now clear to go ahead with implementation of this interface.
should this be tested when config is parsed and not create a controller with invalid config?
Good point. It should fail out at configuration time, not here.

There are still some unresolved bugs regarding initialization at configuration time. Please see https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-pid-control/issues/33 FR. I did not want to complicate this patch by also changing the code that deals with initial configuration parsing, as that should be part of a separate cleanup. I will put a TODO in here, though.
Should margin type use a different value?

This is how it was before. While not part of this patch, you have a valid point, however. I think it would be better to fall back to using whatever the setpoint of this PID loop is, not zero. If input equals setpoint, PID calculations will have no effect, which is a reasonable behavior if unable to come up with a usable value (the zone should already be in failsafe by this point). This will work for both temperature and margin input.
Agreed. Thanks!
